Critical Failure The Ulfen witchguard is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} until the start of their next turn.

Umberweed.name: Umberweed
Umberweed.publicNotes:
The mischievous dragon sprites called draxies have dueled their pixie cousins for the title of ultimate prankster for centuries. They exercise patience and planning to create the perfect pranks, spending months, or even years, on their efforts. One exception to their flighty nature is the elucrea, a lifelong bond between a draxie and a creature they're particularly fond of, typically one with a good sense of humor. According to draxie legend, a little piece of a draxie's spirit remembers being united as the ancient fey dragonet Elucredassa, and that causes draxies to yearn for such connections with others.

Elusive, flighty, and ebullient, sprites are what many villagers first imagine when they hear the terms "fey" or "fairy." While their dispositions vary, all sprites share a connection to magic and a diminutive size. This family of fey shares its name with its slightest and most populous member, the common sprite.

action->Draxie Dust.name: Draxie Dust
action->Draxie Dust.description:
The draxie breathes magical dust in a @Template[cone|distance:15]. Roll [[/r 1d4]] to determine the effect. Each creature in the area must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:15] save or be affected.

The draxie can't use Draxie Dust again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Draxie Dust]]{1d4 rounds}.

  1. The target takes the effects of the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.vLA0q0WOK2YPuJs6]{Charm} spell.
  2. The target loses its last 5 minutes of memory.
  3. The target takes the effects of a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.o4lRVTwSxnOOn5vl]{Sleep} spell.
  4. For 1 minute, the target is in a state of euphoria that makes it @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1}.

Unstable Furniture Archway.name: Unstable Furniture Archway
Unstable Furniture Archway.descriptionHazard: This unsteady pile of furniture is piled to the top of this usually high-ceilinged room. There looks to be some space to squeeze through to the other side, but even the slightest touch causes the stack to destabilize, and there's so much that once it begins to fall, it's difficult to stop.
Unstable Furniture Archway.disable: @Check[athletics|dc:21] to knock the pile over in a safe direction or @Check[thievery|dc:19] (trained) to carefully rearrange the furniture to a stable configuration.
Unstable Furniture Archway.routine: On its initiative, the pile expands into an adjacent space, dealing creatures in that space @Damage[(1d6+4)[bludgeoning]] damage with a @Check[reflex|dc:18|basic] save, pushing any creatures in that space into an adjacent empty space, and making that space impassable until cleared. If no adjacent empty space is available, the pile buries the creature, suffocating it. Clearing a space or pulling a creature out requires a @Check[athletics|dc:15] check.

action->Tumbling Down.name: Tumbling Down
action->Tumbling Down.description:
Trigger A creature moves into a space adjacent to the furniture pile

Effect Part of the pile slides into a space the creature occupies, causing @Damage[(1d6+4)[bludgeoning]] damage with a @Check[reflex|dc:18|basic] save. The furniture pile rolls initiative.

Very Haunted Hollows.name: Very Haunted Hollows
Very Haunted Hollows.descriptionHazard: The spirits of innumerable dryads and peaceful wood elementals, ripped from their bodies as they were turned into furniture, writhe and seethe, lashing out at both living and undead alike.
Very Haunted Hollows.disable:
@Check[diplomacy|dc:20] (trained), @Check[nature|dc:20] (trained), or @Check[religion|dc:20] (trained) to set the spirits to rest or @Check[deception|dc:23], @Check[intimidation|dc:23], or @Check[occultism|dc:23] to convince the spirits that their eternal rest is coming soon.

A PC may make a Strike against AC 19 to destroy a single table or chair in the room, this functions as a successful check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.HCl3pzVefiv9ZKQW]{Aid} another PC attempting to disable the haunt; two total successes are required to disable the haunt. If all of the tables and chairs are destroyed, the haunt is temporarily disabled until dawn of the next day.
Very Haunted Hollows.routine: (two actions) The Haunted Hollows haunt uses one table flip Strike or two chair toss Strikes at random creatures in the area, favoring those who are trying to disable the haunt first. The table flip Strikes originate with any table in the room, destroying the table in the process. The chair toss Strikes originate with any chair or bar stool in the room, destroying that object in the process. If the haunt is not disabled, these objects reform and return to their original positions at dawn of the next day.

action->Warped Wood.name: Warped Wood
action->Warped Wood.description:
Trigger Any living or undead creatures approach within 30 feet of the haunt's locus (the center of the open balcony) inside the tavern

Effect The haunt makes a table flip Strike with a reach of 20 feet against a random creature in the area, and then rolls initiative.

action->Giant Wasp Venom.name: Giant Wasp Venom
action->Giant Wasp Venom.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:19]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 no effect (1 round)

Stage 2 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} (1 round)

action->Implant Eggs.name: Implant Eggs
action->Implant Eggs.description: The Vespiria lays eggs in an adjacent creature that is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious}, exposing it to wasp larva disease.

action->To Me, My Minions.name: To Me, My Minions
action->To Me, My Minions.description: The vespiria has complete control over wasps within 30 feet. All Giant Wasps or Wasp Swarms in range can make a free attack on a target within melee range as normal.

action->Wasp Larva.name: Wasp Larva
action->Wasp Larva.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:19]

Stage 1 carrier with no ill effect ([[/gmr 1d6 #days]]{1d6 days})

Stage 2 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} ([[/gmr 1d3 #days]]{1d3 days})

Stage 3 @Damage[5d6[untyped]] damage, larva emerges (disease ends)

action->Giant Wasp Venom.name: Giant Wasp Venom
action->Giant Wasp Venom.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:22]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 no effect (1 round)

Stage 2 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} (1 round)

action->Implant Eggs.name: Implant Eggs
action->Implant Eggs.description: The Vespiria lays eggs in an adjacent creature that is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious}, exposing it to wasp larva disease.

action->To Me, My Minions.name: To Me, My Minions
action->To Me, My Minions.description: The vespiria queen has complete control over wasps within 30 feet. All giant wasps or wasp swarms in range can make a free attack on a target within melee range as normal.

action->Wasp Larva.name: Wasp Larva
action->Wasp Larva.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:22]

Stage 1 carrier with no ill effect ([[/gmr 1d6 #days]]{1d6 days})

Stage 2 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} ([[/gmr 1d3 #days]]{1d3 days})

Stage 3 @Damage[5d6[untyped]] damage, larva emerges (disease ends)

Veteran Bodyguard.name: Veteran Bodyguard
Veteran Bodyguard.publicNotes:
Hired to protect someone famous or powerful, bodyguards use intimidation, quick wits, and martial skill to keep their charges safe. Such mercenaries might be auxiliaries to a noble's personal guards, but with special directives to safeguard their patrons.

Whether they're hired to wage war, protect a caravan, or infiltrate an impenetrable fortress, there's ample work for mercenaries all over Golarion.

action->Bodyguard's Reprisal.name: Bodyguard's Reprisal
action->Bodyguard's Reprisal.description:
Trigger A creature attacks the subject of bodyguard's defense

Effect The bodyguard makes a Strike against the triggering creature.

action->Bodyguard's Defense.name: Bodyguard's Defense
action->Bodyguard's Defense.description:
The bodyguard grants an adjacent ally a +2 circumstance bonus to AC. This lasts until the start of the bodyguard's next turn or until the ally is no longer adjacent, whichever comes first.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.IfUod2VxNmZMGGPq]{Effect: Bodyguard's Defense}

Veteran Pure Legionnaire.name: Veteran Pure Legionnaire
Veteran Pure Legionnaire.allSavesBonus: +2 on all saves against divine magic

weapon->Scimitar.name: Scimitar
weapon->Scimitar.description: This one-handed curved blade is sharp on one side.

armor->Leather Armor.name: Leather Armor
armor->Leather Armor.description: A mix of flexible and molded boiled leather, a suit of this type of armor provides some protection with maximum flexibility.

action->+2 Status to All Saves Against D.name: +2 Status to All Saves Against Divine Magic

action->May No Mortal Be Beholden.name: May No Mortal Be Beholden
action->May No Mortal Be Beholden.description: When the Pure Legionnaire rolls a success on a save against an effect or spell from the divine tradition, they get a critical success instead.

action->Smite Divine.name: Smite Divine
action->Smite Divine.description: The scimitars of the Pure Legion have been enchanted specifically to take down divine spellcasters. Melee Strikes against clerics, champions, and other creatures capable of casting divine spells do an additional 2d6 mental damage.

action->Sudden Charge.name: Sudden Charge
action->Sudden Charge.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The Pure Legionnaire Strides twice. If they end their movement within melee reach of at least one enemy, they can make a melee Strike against that enemy.

Void Font.name: Void Font
Void Font.descriptionHazard: The font is hidden just under the water's surface. It spews foul brown sludge into the pristine waters, leaving them reeking and polluted as they move downstream. It can be reached without swimming, but not without getting wet.
Void Font.disable: @Check[nature|dc:20] (trained) to draw upon the suppressed Primal energies of this place to cleanse the font, @Check[religion|dc:26] (expert) to suppress the void energies, @Check[thievery|dc:23] to undo the magic sigils allowing the font to operate; two total successes are required to disable the font.
Void Font.reset: The void font deactivates 1 minute after all creatures leave the area but resets immediately thereafter.
Void Font.routine: The void font uses its actions each turn to spew a single void geyser.

action->Void Infused.name: Void Infused
action->Void Infused.description: The foul font can take vitality damage, even though its an object and would normally be immune

action->Spew Foulness.name: Spew Foulness
action->Spew Foulness.description:
Trigger One or more creatures touches the water within 10 feet of the foul font

Effect The font fires off a Void Geyser, causing a rain of foul water. The font then rolls for initiative.

action->Void Geyser.name: Void Geyser
action->Void Geyser.description:
The font shoots its foul brown sludge into the air, and it rains down upon all creatures within 15 feet that aren't completely submerged. Each of those creatures takes @Damage[5d6[void]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:22|basic] save). In addition, those that take damage from the font must make a @Check[fortitude|dc:22] save.

Critical Success The target cannot be sickened by the font for 1 minute.

Success The target is unaffected.

Failure The target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}.

Critical Failure The target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2}.

action->Foul Waters.name: Foul Waters
action->Foul Waters.description: Any creature that is submerged downstream (east) is automatically exposed to Spew Foulness at the start of its turn or when it enters those waters, except the damage is reduced with a @Check[fortitude|dc:22|basic] save instead of Reflex.

Weak Air Scamp.name: Weak Air Scamp
Weak Air Scamp.publicNotes:
A pale blue head and paper-thin wings peek out from the cloud that clings to the air scamp. Air scamps are short-sighted and flighty, even relative to their kin; they are as likely to fly recklessly into battle as they are to whine in terror at a loud noise.

Elemental scamps are bat-like critters marked by elemental powers. Scamps are dispatched from the Elemental Planes by more powerful residents or called to the Universe by neophyte summoners. All scamps have a hint of magical power due to a lingering connection to their home plane, which they largely use to pull simple pranks.

Scamps rapidly form a pecking order of cleverness. Humanoids often confuse scamps when meeting such creatures for the first time. These confused scamps usually resort to an escalating series of pranks and mischief, seeing what they can get away with to establish their place in the hierarchy.

action->Fog Vision.name: Fog Vision
action->Fog Vision.description: The air scamp ignores the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition from fog and mist.

action->Sirocco Breath.name: Sirocco Breath
action->Sirocco Breath.description:
The air scamp creates cutting winds in a @Template[cone|distance:15] that deal @Damage[(2d6-4)[slashing]|options:area-damage] damage to each creature within the area (@Check[reflex|dc:15|basic|options:area-effect] save). A creature that fails its save is also pushed back 10 feet.

The air scamp can't use Sirocco Breath again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Sirocco Breath]]{1d4 rounds}.

Weak Animated Flame.name: Weak Animated Flame
Weak Animated Flame.publicNotes:
Although arguably quite friendly, fire scamps are considered far more dangerous than their kin. They delight in fire and playing pranks on everyone they befriend. Even given time to understand others' dislike of fire, most fire scamps enjoy the feel of flames enough to constantly test their limits.

Compared to the nations of other scamps, the nations on the Plane of Fire are by far the strongest. This backing inspires fire scamps to challenge authority more quickly than the others.

Elemental scamps are bat-like critters marked by elemental powers. Scamps are dispatched from the Elemental Planes by more powerful residents or called to the Universe by neophyte summoners. All scamps have a hint of magical power due to a lingering connection to their home plane, which they largely use to pull simple pranks.

Scamps rapidly form a pecking order of cleverness. Humanoids often confuse scamps when meeting such creatures for the first time. These confused scamps usually resort to an escalating series of pranks and mischief, seeing what they can get away with to establish their place in the hierarchy.

action->Panic of Failure Foreseen.name: Panic of Failure Foreseen
action->Panic of Failure Foreseen.description: If the animated flame leaves the village, willingly or otherwise, it becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} for 2 rounds.

action->Price of Failure.name: Price of Failure
action->Price of Failure.description: If the animated flame starts its turn outside the village after it arrives, it dissipates.

action->Smoke Vision.name: Smoke Vision
action->Smoke Vision.description: The animated flame ignores the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition from smoke.

action->Flame Breath.name: Flame Breath
action->Flame Breath.description:
The animated flame breathes flames in a @Template[cone|distance:15] that deals @Damage[(2d4-4)[fire]|options:area-damage] damage to each creature within the area (@Check[reflex|dc:15|basic|options:area-effect] save). Creatures that fail the save also take @Damage[1d4[persistent,fire]] damage.

The animated flame can't use Flame Breath again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Flame Breath]]{1d4 rounds}.

Weak Bottlenose Dolphin.name: Weak Bottlenose Dolphin
Weak Bottlenose Dolphin.publicNotes:
The bottlenose dolphin is the most common and widespread species of dolphin. They are social predators who hunt shallow seas and rivers in large family groups called pods. Sailors are fond of bottlenose dolphins and frequently tell of how they've saved drowning mariners or protected crew from sharks with blows from their powerful snouts.

Dolphins encompass a wide range of aquatic mammals, all of which are social, intelligent, and widespread throughout the world's oceans.

action->Aquatic Echolocation 120 feet.name: Aquatic Echolocation 120 feet
action->Aquatic Echolocation 120 feet.description: A bottlenose dolphin can use its hearing as a precise sense at the listed range, but only underwater.

action->Deep Breath.name: Deep Breath
action->Deep Breath.description: A bottlenose dolphin can hold its breath for 2 hours.

action->Ramming Speed.name: Ramming Speed
action->Ramming Speed.description:
The bottlenose dolphin @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.c8TGiZ48ygoSPofx]{Swims} twice and then makes a snout Strike. As long as it moved at least 20 feet, it gains a +1 circumstance bonus to its attack roll.

A Large or smaller creature hit by this attack must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:14] save or be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round.

Weak Gluttonous Geode.name: Weak Gluttonous Geode
Weak Gluttonous Geode.publicNotes:
The vast ranks of earth elementals have been slow to respond to the return of the elemental lords and the Planes of Metal and Wood. These events have not broken the mountains, nor have they blown away the sands.

Earthy Emotions

Earth elementals talk even less than most elementals. They're ponderous, weighing decisions so slowly they can crush the energy from a discussion. Their foremost concern is whether a situation can be endured. Though a rare or resplendent treasure might entice an earth elemental, it's difficult to spur any sense of urgency in them without the presence of an immediate threat.

action->Attach.name: Attach
action->Attach.description: The geode Leaps up to 15 feet and makes a crystal teeth Strike. If it hits a creature larger than itself, it can attach to that creature. Doing so is like Grabbing the creature ([[/act escape dc=15]]), but the geode moves with that creature rather than holding it in place. The geode is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} while attached. If the geode is killed or pushed away while attached to a creature, that creature takes @Damage[1[bleed]]{1 persistent bleed} damage. Escaping the attached geode or removing the geode in other ways doesn't cause bleed damage.

action->Gnaw.name: Gnaw
action->Gnaw.description:
Requirements The geode is attached to a creature

Effect The geode deals @Damage[1d4[bludgeoning]] damage to the creature it's attached to (@Check[fortitude|dc:15|basic] save).

Weak Water Wisp.name: Weak Water Wisp
Weak Water Wisp.publicNotes:
Water wisps are swimming spheres of foam and water, perpetually humming with a wash of soft sounds. They're gentle, nurturing, and quick to help anyone in need.

Wisps are tiny elemental beings that emerged during the creation of the Elemental Planes. The first wisps roamed the Inner Sphere in shifting symphonies that traded members with their every meeting. These symphonies of free wisps created music out of their combined resonances, but when the evil Elemental Lords realized the value of the wisps' resonance, they captured whole symphonies for use as servants.

Wisps attune to each other and to those they surround themselves with. This attunement makes them naturally supportive allies. Free wisps still roam the Inner Sphere and the Material Plane, but they're usually shy and hide themselves from strangers. However, they happily offer their service to those who show them kindness. They especially find themselves drawn to spellcasters who practice elemental magic; these wisps usually watch from afar but sometimes approach those who seem safe to become familiars or comrades.

Free wisps who find one another become close almost immediately. They get especially excited when they find wisps of elements other than their own, showing none of the animosity some elementals exhibit toward other types. Instead, they join in an excited dance, emitting resonances that faintly echo the symphonies of ancient days.

action->Mist Vision.name: Mist Vision
action->Mist Vision.description: The water wisp ignores the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition from mist and fog.

action->Accord Essence.name: Accord Essence
action->Accord Essence.description:
Trigger An ally within 30 feet that benefited from the wisp's resonance in the last hour is targeted by an attack

Effect The wisp detonates itself in a small elemental explosion that gives temporary Hit Points equal to half the wisp's current Hit Points to allies within @Template[emanation|distance:30]{30 feet} that have benefited from the wisp's resonance in the last hour. These temporary Hit Points last 1 hour.

A wisp that uses this reaction is permanently destroyed, and it can be restored only by a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.6dDtGIUerazSHIOu]{Wish} spell or similarly powerful effect. If an ability would prevent the wisp's destruction (for instance, if the wisp is summoned and would merely be dismissed), Accord Essence has no effect.

action->Resonance.name: Resonance
action->Resonance.description:
30 feet. All wisps vibrate at a frequency attuned to their element, resonating with and empowering all creatures and effects sharing that trait.

A creature in the area gains a +1 status bonus to attack and damage rolls for effects with the water trait; a creature with the elemental and water traits gains this bonus to all attack and damage rolls.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.1dwMVgBHfT4qO4OS]{Effect: Resonance}

action->Drench.name: Drench
action->Drench.description:
The wisp puts out all fires in a single 5-foot square.

It extinguishes non-magical fire of that size or smaller automatically and attempts to counteract magical fires (counteract modifier [[/r 1d20+6 #Counteract]]{+6}).

action->In Concert.name: In Concert
action->In Concert.description: When a water wisp rolls a critical failure on a check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.HCl3pzVefiv9ZKQW]{Aid}, they get a failure instead, and when they roll a success, they get a critical success instead.

action->Body Bash.name: Body Bash
action->Body Bash.description:
Frequency once per minute

Effect The wood beetle swings its body around, targeting up to two adjacent creatures and dealing @Damage[1d4[bludgeoning]] damage with a @Check[reflex|dc:14|basic] save.

Weak Wood Scamp.name: Weak Wood Scamp
Weak Wood Scamp.publicNotes:
These moss colonies coalesce over a century into the rough facsimile of a large sloth, right down to mimicking the unique structure of the animal's fur that attracts additional fungi and pollinating insects. Unless summoned or attacked, they rarely leave the trees upon which they first formed.

At first glance, wood elementals might not seem to have the same destructive potential as their cousins from the Planes of Fire, Water, or Air, but don't be fooled. The woods can be a dangerous place.

Though some resemble animals, the elemental beasts presented here are still plants, and their life cycles reflect it. Vegetable lambs grow on rooted stalks, from which they can't be removed until they've matured (or perhaps ripened), leaving them dependent on their immediate surroundings for food. Moss sloths are little more than lumps of green fluff for the first century of their existence, only gaining limited mobility once they can grow their defensive wooden claws.

Wild But Unwild

Many wood elementals are created by kizidhars and other powerful creatures on the Plane of Wood and placed in rote roles. Populating nature preserves and sprawling estates, they can be unsure how to behave if released into the wild. They're essentially born domesticated and will likely act far differently than the wild creatures they mimic, even in natural environments. Their natural predators are few, putting the elementals at less risk, although they're still sometimes eaten by giant termites or captured by some as pets.

A Brain By Any Other Name

Even if Lady Shumunue taught the wood elementals' ancestors to mimic animals, a wood elemental's consciousness is contained not in a brain but in its root system. Entities like nursery crawlers, living groves, and carved beasts use this to their advantage. That an elemental's wooden body can be carved and crafted, apparently without lasting harm, implies that they might not feel pain so long as their roots remain undamaged.

action->Breathe Pollen.name: Breathe Pollen
action->Breathe Pollen.description: The wood scamp breathes choking pollen in a @Template[cone|distance:15] that deals @Damage[(2d6-4)[poison]|options:area-damage] damage to each creature within the area (@Check[reflex|dc:15|basic|options:area-effect] save; creatures who don't need to breathe are immune). The wood scamp can't Breathe Pollen again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Breathe Pollen]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Thorn Puncture.name: Thorn Puncture
action->Thorn Puncture.description: The wood scamp breaks off one of its thorn-like claws in the target's skin, dealing 1 persistent bleed damage until the thorn is removed, which requires an Interact action. This damage is cumulative with each thorn caught in a creature's skin.

Weak Wood Wisp.name: Weak Wood Wisp
Weak Wood Wisp.publicNotes:
Like other wisps, wood wisps roam their plane and attune to other wisps, wandering with them in symphonies. Because of their willingness to bond, wood wisps appear outside their home plane more than other wood elementals, though they're still relatively rare compared to other wisps.

Wood wisps resemble coconuts trailed by thick nests of branches that cover and conceal even deeper webs of thorny vines. They are, unfortunately, both unaware of the pain these thorns can cause fleshy creatures and very physically affectionate in their eagerness to offer assistance.

action->Accord Essence.name: Accord Essence
action->Accord Essence.description:
Trigger An ally within 30 feet that benefited from the wisp's resonance in the last hour is targeted by an attack

Effect The wisp detonates itself in a small elemental explosion of leaves and pollen. This gives temporary Hit Points equal to half the wisp's current HP to all allies within 30 feet that have benefited from the wisp's resonance aura in the past hour. These temporary Hit Points last 1 hour.

A wisp that uses this reaction is permanently destroyed and can be restored only by a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.6dDtGIUerazSHIOu]{Wish} ritual or similarly powerful effect. If an ability would prevent the wisp's destruction (for instance, if the wisp is summoned and would merely be dismissed), Accord Essence has no effect.

action->Resonance.name: Resonance
action->Resonance.description:
30 feet.

All wisps vibrate at a frequency attuned to their element, resonating with and empowering all creatures and effects sharing that trait. A creature in the area gains a +1 status bonus to attack and damage rolls for effects with the plant or wood trait; a creature with the elemental trait and either plant trait or wood trait gains this bonus to all attack and damage rolls. For wood wisps, this bonus also applies to nonmagical wooden weapons, such as staves and clubs.

action->In Concert.name: In Concert
action->In Concert.description: When a wood wisp rolls a critical failure on a check to Aid, they get a failure instead, and when they roll a success, they get a critical success instead.

Weak Xurgimoth.name: Weak Xurgimoth
Weak Xurgimoth.publicNotes:
The magic that flows through primal dragons can manifest more animalistic or bestial features in a given type of dragon. Notably among these are the massive paired horns of the horned dragon. While their bulky frames, natural coloration, and prominent ridged scales are all remarkable in their own way, it's the horns that are most obvious and striking at first glance. Horned dragons use their horns to impale their prey in a quick and brutal display of their might. They are generally contemplative and have a fixation on knowledge and self-discipline, traits belied by their bestial appearance. As a result, horned dragons are generally more open to speaking with outsiders.

Dragons come in myriad forms, with many having magical abilities or connections to magic. Some dragons draw greater power from magic than others, allowing them to manifest abilities or alter their physiques with prolonged exposure to magic. These dragons become more powerful as they age and strengthen their connections with their magical origins. Scholars debate the classification of these dragons, with some preferring the name magical dragons and others using traditional dragons due to their connection to specific magical traditions. Regardless of their names, these dragons share a number of characteristics: their ability to tap into magical energies, intensified might and cunning as they grow older, and an inclination to hoard vast amounts of treasure and wealth.

action->Twisting Tail.name: Twisting Tail
action->Twisting Tail.description:
Trigger A creature within reach of the dragon's tail uses a move action or leaves a square during a move action it's using

Effect The dragon makes a tail Strike at the creature with a –2 penalty. If the Strike hits, the dragon disrupts the creature's action.

action->Draconic Frenzy.name: Draconic Frenzy
action->Draconic Frenzy.description: The dragon makes two claw Strikes and one horn Strike in any order.

action->Draconic Momentum.name: Draconic Momentum
action->Draconic Momentum.description: The dragon recharges their Poison Breath whenever they score a critical hit with a Strike.

action->Forest Passage.name: Forest Passage
action->Forest Passage.description: The horned dragon ignores any difficult terrain caused by plants, such as bushes, vines, and undergrowth. Even plants manipulated by magic don't impede their progress.

action->Impaling Charge.name: Impaling Charge
action->Impaling Charge.description:
Requirements The dragon doesn't have a creature impaled on their horn

Effect The dragon attempts to gore a foe. They Stride, then attempt a horn Strike. On a hit, the target becomes impaled on the dragon's horn. The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} while on the horn (and can attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape} as normal). The dragon doesn't need to use additional actions to keep the impaled creature grabbed. If the dragon moves, they bring the grabbed creature along with them.

action->Poison Breath.name: Poison Breath
action->Poison Breath.description:
The dragon breathes a toxic cloud that deals @Damage[(9d6-4)[poison]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[cone|distance:40] (@Check[fortitude|dc:23|basic|options:area-effect] save).

They can't use Poison Breath again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Poison Breath]]{1d4 rounds}.

Whippoorwill Con Rit.name: Whippoorwill Con Rit
Whippoorwill Con Rit.publicNotes:
The con rit is a hulking aquatic centipede that has traded its hundreds of legs for just as many fins. This sea insect swims with a grace that is just as majestic as it is unnerving. The con rit is dark brown on its dorsal side and sickly yellow on its ventral surface. This makes it much more difficult to spot, whether looking from above or below. Its exoskeleton is as hard as iron, and the shifting of its plates makes an elongated, eerie ringing sound as it swims.

Many once thought the con rit to be a dragon of some kind. This was due not only to its massive size but also to its ability to launch its venom in a concentrated blast. It would use this technique to shoot birds out of the sky or knock sailors off ships. Their movement through the water is also not entirely dissimilar to that of dragons. Those who seek out a con rit's lair in search of treasure are usually disappointed (when they aren't eaten alive by the huge insect).

There are legends that a con rit, much like a phoenix, is reborn after its death. This, however, is not the case. A con rit will make a nest far below the surface of its territory, usually in underwater caves. Throughout its life, a con rit will lay thousands of eggs in its cave that will never hatch. The con rit will eat any egg that gets too old, but there are always large numbers of them remaining. When a con rit dies, it releases a strong-smelling chemical into the air and water that triggers the hatching process. The eggs will slowly crack open within the month, and hundreds of baby con rits will begin to fight each other for territory. By year's end, one will win and reach full maturity. This cycle is what has led to the legends of endless rebirth. Other stories say that every generation of the con rit is ever so slightly smaller, leading to tales of ancient con rits that were hundreds of feet long. However, the size of such legendary insects has yet to be confirmed by scholars who study such things.

action->Con Rit Venom.name: Con Rit Venom
action->Con Rit Venom.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:23];

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[1d10[poison]] (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[2d10[poison]] and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} (1 round);

Stage 3 2d10 poison, off-guard, and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} (1 round)

action->Spit Venom.name: Spit Venom
action->Spit Venom.description:
The con rit spits a propulsive blast of venom that deals @Damage[(2d10-2)[poison],(2d10-2)[bludgeoning]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[line|distance:30] (@Check[fortitude|dc:23|basic|options:area-effect] save). Creatures who fail their save are also pushed 10 feet.

The con rit cannot use Spit Venom again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Spit Venom]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Undulate.name: Undulate
action->Undulate.description: The con rit Swims. During this movement, it can pass through spaces as narrow as 5 feet without Squeezing.

Whippoorwill Electric Eel.name: Whippoorwill Electric Eel
Whippoorwill Electric Eel.publicNotes:
Usually found in freshwater rivers and lakes, an electric eel is not particularly aggressive, but its ability to stun predators and prey alike can be dangerous to larger creatures searching for their next meal. Electric eels are more closely related to catfish than to other eels.

Although these long, narrow fish share similarities in appearance, eels are a diverse group of creatures.

action->Stunning Shock.name: Stunning Shock
action->Stunning Shock.description:
A creature critically hit by the electric eel's tail must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:15] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1}.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 2}.

Critical Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 3}.

Whippoorwill Giant Moray Eel.name: Whippoorwill Giant Moray Eel
Whippoorwill Giant Moray Eel.publicNotes:
Giant moray eels dwell in warm, tropical waters and build lairs in narrow, twisting caves made of coral. Their size, speed, and powerful bite make them dangerous to divers and fishers. Giant moray eels have rubbery hides that secrete a layer of mucus, making them difficult to harm with some weapons.

Although these long, narrow fish share similarities in appearance, eels are a diverse group of creatures.

action->Ambush.name: Ambush
action->Ambush.description:
Trigger A target creature passes within 20 feet of the giant moray eel's hiding place and has not detected the giant moray eel

Effect The giant moray eel lunges out of its hiding place, Swims directly toward the triggering creature, and makes a jaws Strike against it. The target creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} to this attack.

action->Pharyngeal Jaws.name: Pharyngeal Jaws
action->Pharyngeal Jaws.description:
Requirements The giant moray eel has a creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} in its jaws

Effect The giant moray eel uses its second set of jaws to pull the prey into its gullet. The eel deals @Damage[(1d6+2)[piercing]] damage to the grabbed creature and gains a +2 circumstance bonus to its Swallow Whole attempts and to the DC for the creature to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape}. This effect ends if the target Escapes or the giant moray eel Swallows it Whole.

Whippoorwill Pathfinder Protector.name: Whippoorwill Pathfinder Protector
Whippoorwill Pathfinder Protector.publicNotes:
Ghouls stalkers are ravenous undead who haunt graveyards and eat corpses.

Few creatures are more ubiquitous to sinister locations such as lonely graveyards and ruined crypts than the flesh-eating undead known as ghouls.

action->Consume Flesh.name: Consume Flesh
action->Consume Flesh.description:
Requirements The ghoul is adjacent to the corpse of a creature that died within the last hour.

Effect The ghoul devours a chunk of the corpse and regains @Damage[1d6[healing]] Hit Points.

It can regain Hit Points from any given corpse only once.

action->Ghoul Whispers.name: Ghoul Whispers
action->Ghoul Whispers.description:
Requirements A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} creature is within the ghoul's reach

Effect The ghoul whispers dark thoughts and vile cravings into the creature's ears. The creature must save against the forbidden cravings curse.

Forbidden Cravings (curse)

Saving Throw @Check[will|dc:15|traits:curse]

Stage 1 carrier with no ill effects (1 day)

Stage 2 @Damage[2d6[void]] damage and the target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} until it consumes raw meat (1 day)

Stage 3 as stage 2

Stage 4 as stage 2 unless the target has consumed raw meat in the past 24 hours, then it takes @Damage[4d6[void]] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} until it consumes raw meat;

Stage 5 if the creature has eaten raw meat in the past 24 hours, it dies and rises as a ghoul, if not, it returns to stage 4

action->Swift Stroke.name: Swift Stroke
action->Swift Stroke.description: The ghoul swims up to half its Speed. This movement doesn't trigger reactions.

Whippoorwill Piranha Swarm.name: Whippoorwill Piranha Swarm
Whippoorwill Piranha Swarm.publicNotes:
More teeth and fury than body, few fish command as much fear and anxiety as the piranha. They move almost exclusively in schools, overwhelming larger creatures with sheer numbers and ferocity. Piranhas aggress toward sudden disturbances in the water and can smell blood from far away. Harvested piranha teeth serve as excellent cutting tools.

Swimming in vast shoals through open ocean underneath the sparkling sun, lurking deep in the muddy beds of rivers, or schooling in pristine lakes, fish are found nearly anywhere there is water.

action->Blood Scent.name: Blood Scent
action->Blood Scent.description: The piranha swarm can smell blood in the water from up to 1 mile away.

action->Feeding Frenzy.name: Feeding Frenzy
action->Feeding Frenzy.description:
Each enemy in the swarm's space takes @Damage[(2d6-2)[piercing]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:18|basic] save).

A creature that fails the save also takes @Damage[1d6[bleed]] and takes a -2 circumstance penalty to their Reflex saves against Feeding Frenzy while this damage continues, as the piranhas' frenzy increases in intensity when they smell blood.

Wind Buffets (1-2).name: Wind Buffets (1-2)
Wind Buffets (1-2).descriptionHazard: The wind grows fierce as a small planar fissure opens, blowing around leaves and creatures alike.
Wind Buffets (1-2).disable: @Check[type:arcana,nature,thievery|dc:15] (trained) two times to counter the planar energies.
Wind Buffets (1-2).routine:
(3 actions) On its turn each round, the wind begins blowing fiercely from a random direction. All creatures must attempt a @Check[type:reflex|dc:15] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is moved 5 feet in the direction the wind is blowing.

Failure The creature is moved 10 feet in the direction the wind is blowing and is knocked @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

Critical Failure The creature is moved 10 feet in the direction the wind is blowing, is knocked prone, and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1}.

action->An Intense Gust!.name: An Intense Gust!
action->An Intense Gust!.description:
A non-elemental creature approaches within 20 feet

Effect All creatures within 20 feet must attempt a @Check[type:reflex|dc:18] save; results are as if the hazard used its normal routine. The hazard then rolls initiative.

action->Body Bash.name: Body Bash
action->Body Bash.description:
Frequency once per minute

Effect The wood beetle swings its body around, targeting up to two adjacent creatures and dealing @Damage[1d8[bludgeoning]] damage with a @Check[reflex|dc:14|basic] save.

Wood Scamp (Quest 22).name: Wood Scamp (Quest 22)
Wood Scamp (Quest 22).publicNotes:
These moss colonies coalesce over a century into the rough facsimile of a large sloth, right down to mimicking the unique structure of the animal's fur that attracts additional fungi and pollinating insects. Unless summoned or attacked, they rarely leave the trees upon which they first formed.

At first glance, wood elementals might not seem to have the same destructive potential as their cousins from the Planes of Fire, Water, or Air, but don't be fooled. The woods can be a dangerous place.

Though some resemble animals, the elemental beasts presented here are still plants, and their life cycles reflect it. Vegetable lambs grow on rooted stalks, from which they can't be removed until they've matured (or perhaps ripened), leaving them dependent on their immediate surroundings for food. Moss sloths are little more than lumps of green fluff for the first century of their existence, only gaining limited mobility once they can grow their defensive wooden claws.

Wild But Unwild

Many wood elementals are created by kizidhars and other powerful creatures on the Plane of Wood and placed in rote roles. Populating nature preserves and sprawling estates, they can be unsure how to behave if released into the wild. They're essentially born domesticated and will likely act far differently than the wild creatures they mimic, even in natural environments. Their natural predators are few, putting the elementals at less risk, although they're still sometimes eaten by giant termites or captured by some as pets.

A Brain By Any Other Name

Even if Lady Shumunue taught the wood elementals' ancestors to mimic animals, a wood elemental's consciousness is contained not in a brain but in its root system. Entities like nursery crawlers, living groves, and carved beasts use this to their advantage. That an elemental's wooden body can be carved and crafted, apparently without lasting harm, implies that they might not feel pain so long as their roots remain undamaged.

action->Breathe Pollen.name: Breathe Pollen
action->Breathe Pollen.description: The wood scamp breathes choking pollen in a @Template[cone|distance:15] that deals @Damage[2d6[poison]|options:area-damage] damage to each creature within the area (@Check[reflex|dc:17|basic|options:area-effect] save; creatures who don't need to breathe are immune). The wood scamp can't Breathe Pollen again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Breathe Pollen]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Thorn Puncture.name: Thorn Puncture
action->Thorn Puncture.description: The wood scamp breaks off one of its thorn-like claws in the target's skin, dealing 1 persistent bleed damage until the thorn is removed, which requires an Interact action. This damage is cumulative with each thorn caught in a creature's skin.

action->Hellish Spellstrike.name: Hellish Spellstrike
action->Hellish Spellstrike.description: Yollen's signature spellstrike channels the ill will of Hell. He casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.6DfLZBl8wKIV03Iq]{Ignition}, then makes a melee attack strike with his greataxe. If he successfully hits, he deals an additional 2d6 damage (4d6 on a critical hit) on top of the damage from ignition and the greataxe. This counts as two attacks for the purposes of multiple attack penalty, but the penalty does not apply until after Yollen completes this ability. Yollen cannot use Hellish Spellstrike again until he has recharge it using a single action with the concentrate trait or cast his conflux spell.

action->Mountain of Iron.name: Mountain of Iron
action->Mountain of Iron.description:
Frequency once per hour

Effect Yollen draws upon the power of the warshard to bolster his health. He gains fast healing 5 for 1 minute.

Young Giant Viper.name: Young Giant Viper
Young Giant Viper.publicNotes:
The giant viper's fangs are a frightening sight, with injection tubes as long as daggers. The sheer amount of venom injected by a giant viper can cause severe blood clotting and leave a victim utterly drained of vitality.

Snakes come in an array of forms, from jungle-dwelling constrictors that wrap around their prey to venomous vipers with deadly bites. Regardless, all snakes consume their prey whole by unhinging their jaws and using powerful muscles to move the food down their throats and into their stomachs.

action->Coiled Strike (Special).name: Coiled Strike (Special)
action->Coiled Strike (Special).description:
As Reactive Strike, but the snake can use this reaction only if it's Coiled.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.ReactiveStrike]

action->Coil.name: Coil
action->Coil.description: The giant viper uses an action to coil itself. While Coiled, the reach of its fangs is 10 feet and it has the Reactive Strike reaction. After the giant viper Strikes with its fangs, it becomes uncoiled.

action->Giant Viper Venom.name: Giant Viper Venom
action->Giant Viper Venom.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:15]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 2 @Damage[1d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}

Young Warg.name: Young Warg
Young Warg.publicNotes:
Wargs hunt in packs like wolves, but their penchant for taunting victims makes them easy to distinguish from their cousins. Orcs and hobgoblins frequently recruit wargs. Most wargs are amenable to this arrangement, but if food should run out, wargs are more than willing to integrate goblinoid flesh into their diet.

The warg is an intelligent and malevolent wolf that dwells among goblins, hobgoblins, orcs, and violent humanoids.

action->Pack Attack.name: Pack Attack
action->Pack Attack.description: The warg's Strikes deals an extra 1d4 damage to any creature within reach of at least two of the warg's allies.

strike-melee->Jaws.description: Requirements The zombie has a creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}.

action->Bursting Pustules.name: Bursting Pustules
action->Bursting Pustules.description:

Effect The pustules covering the zombie's flesh rupture, covering adjacent creatures with vile fluid. Creatures adjacent to the zombie become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} unless they succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:18] save.

action->Slow.name: Slow
action->Slow.description: A zombie crow swarm is permanently @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed} and can't use reactions.

action->Swarming Pecks.description: Each enemy in the swarm's space takes @Damage[1d8[piercing]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:17|basic] save)

action->Slow.name: Slow
action->Slow.description: A zombie crow swarm is permanently @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed} and can't use reactions.

action->Swarming Pecks.description: Each enemy in the swarm's space takes @Damage[1d6[piercing]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:16|basic] save)

Zombie Leshy.name: Zombie Leshy
Zombie Leshy.publicNotes:
Plague zombies are infested with horrible contagions.

A zombie's only desire is to consume the living. Unthinking and ever-shambling harbingers of death, zombies stop only when they're destroyed.

condition->Slowed.name: Slowed
condition->Slowed.description: You have fewer actions. Slowed always includes a value. When you regain your actions at the start of your turn, reduce the number of actions you regain by your slowed value. Because slowed has its effect at the start of your turn, you don't immediately lose actions if you become slowed during your turn.

strike-melee->Jaws.name: Jaws
strike-melee->Jaws.description: Requirements The zombie has a creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}.

action->Slow.name: Slow
action->Slow.description: A zombie leshy is permanently @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and can't use reactions

action->Rotten Burst.name: Rotten Burst
action->Rotten Burst.description: When a zombie leshy dies, a burst of twisted primal void energy explodes from its body, restoring @Damage[1d4[healing,void]]{1d4} Hit Points to each undead fungi or plant creature in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30] and killing all natural plants, though merely causing discomfort to creatures with the plant trait. This area is filled with rotten vegetation, becoming difficult terrain.

action->Glide.name: Glide
action->Glide.description: The zombie leshy glides gently through the air, moving 5 feet toward the ground and up to 25 feet forward. As long as the leshy spends at least 1 action gliding each round, it remains in the air at the end of each turn. For the purpose of determining damage from falls, a leaf leshy always treats falls as if they were 20 feet shorter.

action->Zombie Rot.name: Zombie Rot
action->Zombie Rot.description:
An infected creature can't heal damage it takes form zombie rot until it has been cured of the disease

Stage 2 @Damage[1d6[void]] damage (1 day)

Stage 3 @Damage[1d6[void]] damage (1 day)

Stage 4 @Damage[1d6[void]] damage (1 day)

Stage 5 dead, rising as a plague zombie immediately, or a zombie leshy if the creature had the leshy trait.

Zombie Leshy Horde.name: Zombie Leshy Horde
Zombie Leshy Horde.publicNotes:
This shuffling mass of decaying flesh moves with dull but singular focus.

Necromancers most often create these mindless undead as obedient, expendable servitors. Left to its own devices, a zombie seeks only to consume the living, stopping only when its rotting body can no longer hold together.

action->Slow.name: Slow
action->Slow.description: A zombie leshy horde is permanently @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and can't use reactions

action->Grave Tide.description: The zombie leshy horde is less organized than most troops. It can move into other creatures' spaces, and other creatures can move into its spaces. Its spaces are difficult terrain to other creatures.

action->Shambling Onslaught.description:

action->Troop Movement.name: Troop Movement
action->Troop Movement.description: Whenever a troop Strides, it first Forms Up as a free action to condense into a 20-foot-by-20-foot area (minus any missing squares), then moves up to its Speed. This works just like a Gargantuan creature moving; for instance, if any square of the troop enters difficult terrain, the extra movement cost applies to the whole troop.
